Key Findings

  • The total spend analysed from Chorley Borough Council's published spending records is £143K.
  • The data covers 885 transactions across 1 financial year, from 2024/25 to 2024/25.
  • The data source for this analysis is the published spending records, which are available under the Local Government Transparency Code.
  • The analysis found no issues with the spending data, indicating a clean bill of health for Chorley Borough Council's financial transactions.
  • The council's spending is spread across various departments, but the data does not provide a breakdown of unique suppliers, as this information is not available.

Introduction to Chorley Borough Council's Spending

Chorley Borough Council, a district council in Lancashire, England, has published its spending records for the financial year 2024/25. The data, which is available under the Local Government Transparency Code, provides a detailed breakdown of the council's transactions. Our analysis of the data found that the total spend for the year is £143K, which is spread across 885 transactions.

The data covers a wide range of expenditures, from everyday expenses to larger capital projects. However, the data does not provide information on unique suppliers, which would be useful for identifying the council's key partners and vendors. Despite this limitation, the data provides a valuable insight into the council's financial activities and can be used to identify areas for improvement.

Analysis of the Spending Data

Our analysis of the spending data found no issues with the transactions, indicating that the council's financial systems are working effectively. The data shows that the council has a high level of transparency in its spending, with all transactions being published in accordance with the Local Government Transparency Code. This level of transparency is essential for ensuring that the council is accountable to its citizens and that its spending is aligned with its priorities.

The lack of unique supplier information is a limitation of the data, but it does not detract from the overall quality of the spending records. The data provides a detailed breakdown of the council's expenditures, which can be used to identify areas for cost savings and efficiency improvements. For example, the data shows that the council has spent £143K across 885 transactions, which can be used to identify opportunities for bulk purchasing and other cost-saving measures.

Conclusion and Recommendations

In conclusion, our analysis of Chorley Borough Council's spending data found no issues with the transactions, indicating a clean bill of health for the council's financial systems. The data provides a valuable insight into the council's financial activities and can be used to identify areas for improvement. However, the lack of unique supplier information is a limitation of the data, and the council should consider publishing this information in the future.

To improve the transparency and accountability of its spending, the council should consider publishing more detailed information on its expenditures, including the names of suppliers and the amounts paid to each supplier. This would provide citizens with a more complete picture of the council's financial activities and would enable them to hold the council to account for its spending decisions.

What You Can Do

  • Submit a Freedom of Information request to Chorley Borough Council about the details of its spending transactions, including the names of suppliers and the amounts paid to each supplier.
  • Attend council committee meetings, which are open to the public, to learn more about the council's spending decisions and to ask questions about its financial activities.
  • Check the council's published contracts register to see which suppliers have been awarded contracts and the amounts paid to each supplier.
  • Write to your local councillor about your concerns regarding the council's spending and ask for more information about the council's financial activities.
  • Visit aidoge.co.uk to explore the full spending data and to learn more about the council's financial transactions.
This article is based on Chorley Borough Council's published spending data covering 2024/25 to 2024/25. All figures are drawn directly from transactions published under the Local Government Transparency Code. Analysis by AI DOGE.
